items.title: MP Chris d'Entremont says he joined Liberals because of Poilievre's leadership style
Canada's men collect their 1st-ever FIFA U17 World Cup win
items.summary_auto: Elijah Roche scored in the 88th minute and Marius Aiyenero converted a penalty in stoppage time as Canada pulled off a Houdini-like 2-1 win over Uganda on Wednesday for its first-ever victory in nine trips to the FIFA U-17 World Cup.

items.title: Thousands of Alberta nursing care staff vote in favour of strike
items.summary_auto: Nursing care staff represented by the Alberta Union of Provincial Employees have voted 98 per cent in favour of strike action in a vote this week.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Sightings of November's supermoon
items.summary_auto: Stargazers got a celestial treat with the appearance of a supermoon, the second one this year.

items.title: New national emergency alert system proposed in federal budget
items.summary_auto: The federal budget is proposing more than $55 million for a new national emergency alert system, making good on a recommendation from the committee that examined the 2020 mass shooting in Nova Scotia.

items.title: B.C. premier, First Nations call on feds to continue oil tanker ban
items.summary_auto: B.C. Premier David Eby stood with members of numerous First Nations from B.C.’s northern coast on Wednesday to support and sign a declaration that asks Ottawa to continue a moratorium on oil tankers in the province’s northern waters.

items.title: U.S. government shutdown is now the longest in history
items.summary_auto: The government shutdown has entered its 36th day, setting the record as the longest ever, disrupting the lives of millions of Americans with federal program cuts, missed paychecks, flight delays while costing the U.S. at least $10 billion per week, according to estimates.

items.title: As soaring AI stocks take a turn, investors say not to panic yet
items.summary_auto: Markets in Asia and Europe took a hit Wednesday before Wall Street's muted open. For months, markets have ignored elevated interest rates, stubborn inflation, trade turmoil and a patchy global economy, leading some to worry about whether hopes surrounding AI were creating a bubble that could burst.

items.title: Trade talks with Trump ‘not yet revived’ since anti-tariff ad apology: Carney
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney gave no indication trade talks with the United States will resume any time soon, despite apologizing to U.S. President Donald Trump who abruptly ended negotiations over an ad campaign.

items.title: Aid groups call for urgent access of shelter, food items into Gaza as winter nears
items.summary_auto: Thousands of boxes filled with shelter items and food are sitting idle in Jordan, Egypt and Israel, humanitarian agencies say, warning that very little aid is making its way into Gaza nearly four weeks after a ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel began.

items.title: Shane Bieber returning to Blue Jays after exercising $16M US option in contract
items.summary_auto: Starting pitcher Shane Bieber will return to the Toronto Blue Jays, with the team saying Wednesday he exercised his player option for the 2026 campaign.

items.title: Japan sends in the military to deal with surge in bear attacks
items.summary_auto: Japan deployed troops on Wednesday to help contain a surge of bear attacks that have terrorized residents in a mountainous region in the northern prefecture of Akita.

items.title: RECAP | U.S. Supreme Court justices question Trump’s sweeping use of tariffs
Moose set loose in B.C. Interior with the help of a Canadian flag
items.summary_auto: On a sleepy fall morning in the quiet woods of B.C. Interior, a young moose trapped inside a paddock was led to freedom by an animal lover and a Canadian flag.

items.title: Fish plant fire a devastating loss for many, says St. Mary's mayor
items.summary_auto: St. Mary’s Mayor Steve Ryan describes Tuesday night’s events as “a perfect storm.” The town's fish plant had burned down in the middle of a storm that brought hurricane-force winds. Those weather conditions are expected to continue through Wednesday.

items.title: 'Cloud' of tension between Aboriginal title and private property ownership lands in B.C.
items.summary_auto: Decades ago one of B.C. 's top judges described tensions between the legal concept of Aboriginal title and the reality of private property ownership as a "cloud." Last week, just as Southin predicted, the "cloud" touched down in Richmond.

items.title: Alberta unions promise ‘big’ response to use of notwithstanding clause — but can they deliver?
items.summary_auto: On the heels of the Alberta government’s decision to use the Charter's notwithstanding clause to force striking teachers back to work, the provincial labour movement is flirting with a tactic that its leaders say would be “big and bold and unprecedented" — but they’re still not quite ready to flip the switch.

items.title: Alberta unions promise ‘big and bold’ response — but can they deliver?
items.summary_auto: On the heels of the Alberta government’s decision to use the Charter's notwithstanding clause to force striking teachers back to work, the provincial labour movement is flirting with a tactic that its leaders say would be “big and bold and unprecedented" — but they’re still not quite ready to flip the switch.

items.title: At least 85 dead after Typhoon Kalmaegi floods Philippines, engulfing entire communities
items.summary_auto: Typhoon Kalmaegi has left at least 85 people dead and 75 others missing in the central Philippines, many in widespread flooding that trapped people on their roofs and swept away cars in a hard-hit province still recovering from a deadly earthquake, officials said Wednesday.

items.title: 'Bring my dad home,' pleads son of Sask. man missing since June 2022
items.summary_auto: The family of Drew Ballantyne continues to look for information about what might have happened to him. Ballantyne was last seen in June 2022.

items.title: Winnipeg veterinarian ordered to end practice after surgery error led to cat’s leg being amputated
items.summary_auto: A Winnipeg pet owner whose cat Shadow needed a hind leg amputated after an error during surgery says she is glad the veterinarian is being ordered to end his practice in 2026.

items.title: Drought could threaten salmon returning to N.S. rivers to spawn, say conservationists
items.summary_auto: In October and November, Atlantic salmon return from their ocean feeding grounds to the rivers where they were born, looking for an ideal place to spawn. But in Nova Scotia, the ongoing drought is threatening some fish as they attempt to complete an important step in their life cycle.

items.title: Islanders asked for input on new rules for unregulated beauty services in P.E.I.
items.summary_auto: The province's Hairdressers Act regulates hairdressing services, but things like skin care, nail care and hair removal aren't covered by the legislation. That means providers don't need to be licensed or have credentials.

items.title: This Texas county turned Republican for 1st time in over a century. A year on, voters say they have no regrets
items.summary_auto: CBC News recently travelled to Starr County, Texas, to get a better sense of how voters feel one year after Donald Trump returned to the White House. Trump flipped this county in 2024, becoming the first Republican presidential nominee to win it in 132 years — though residents are divided on his policies.

items.title: How this Windsor, Ont., mom navigates ARFID, her son's little-known eating disorder
items.summary_auto: While ARFID is an eating disorder, it differs from anorexia or bulimia because it isn’t driven by concerns about weight or body image. Instead, it’s a severe, sometimes debilitating sensory reaction to many or most types of food.

items.title: One of Trudeau’s most important climate policies is on the chopping block. Can Ottawa's Plan B get buy-in?
items.summary_auto: Four years after unveiling plans for a limit on all oil and natural gas industry emissions in Canada, the federal government is, in all likelihood, scrapping the cap. It’s the latest move by Prime Minister Mark Carney to put more emphasis on economic growth and less attention on climate action.

items.title: Trump's claims of Christian persecution in Nigeria bump up against facts
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to go "guns-a-blazing" into Nigeria over what he claims to be deadly persecution of Christians are prompting pushback in the West African nation.

items.title: Federal budget charts difficult path out of current crisis — with small margin of error
items.summary_auto: The 2025 federal budget plots a path for the Canadian economy to emerge from the current crisis. But it also highlights just how deep a hole the economy is in right now and how small the margin for error is as Canada navigates the perils of a trade war.

items.title: The Assembly gave Jann Arden her best-ever interview. Here's how
items.summary_auto: The Assembly — a global hit where celebrities are interviewed by people on the autism spectrum — is getting a Canadian version. As the latest show putting neurodivergence in the spotlight, it has received mixed reviews. Some call it heartwarming, others say it's condescending.

items.title: Cineplex is launching 'surprise' movie premieres, but will it help bring audiences back to theatres?
items.summary_auto: Cineplex is hoping an element of surprise will get people into seats at a time when movie theatres are short on blockbusters. The theatre chain’s Monday Surprise Premieres, launching Nov. 10, promise an advanced screening of an unreleased movie at a discounted price.

items.title: Anglican Diocese of Edmonton questions use of notwithstanding clause on teachers’ strike
items.summary_auto: The Anglican Diocese of Edmonton is expressing concerns about the Alberta government's use of the notwithstanding clause to force striking teachers back to work.
